Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/con.title: Contributing
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/con.description: First off, thanks for taking the time to contribute! Contributions are what makes the open-source community such an amazing place to learn, inspire, and create. Any contributions you make will benefit everybody else and are greatly appreciated.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/cos.title: Costs
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/cos.description: It is important to note that the Keypom contract is 100% FEE FREE and will remain that way for the foreseeable future. This contract is a public good and is meant to inspire change in the NEAR ecosystem.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Int.title: Introduction
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Int.description: To view our debut talk at NEARCON 2022, click here.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Int.title: Our Solution
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Int.description: Keypom allows for the creation of highly customizable access keys. These keys can be thought of as having their

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/lic.title: License
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/lic.description: This project is licensed under the GPL License.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/pas.title: Password Protected Keys
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/pas.description: Password protecting key uses is an extremely powerful feature that can unlock many use-cases. Keypom has baked flexibility and customization

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/que.title: Query Information From Keypom
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/que.description: Keypom allows users to query a suite of different information from the contract. This information can be broken down into two separate objects that are returned. JsonDrops and JsonKeys.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/tes.title: Running the Keypom Tests
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/tes.description: We have put together a suite of test cases that can be found in the tests folder. These range anywhere from simple config tests all the way to full blown ticketing and POAPs.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: What are Drop Configurations?
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: What sets Keypom apart from the basic NEAR Linkdrop? One major aspect is that Keypom allows for LOADS of customization!

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Drop Configurations
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: Drop Customizations via the DropConfig object passed into create_drop can help adjust the properties and behaviors of a drop to achieve specific use-cases.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Function Call Drops
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: Function call drops are by far the most powerful feature that Keypom provides. FC drops allow any method on any

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Fungible Token Drops
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: A Fungible Token drop is also a light wrapper around the simple drop. It works very similarly to how its NFT

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Types of Drops
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: There are four types of drops, each with different types of assets. These drops can be claimed either with a brand new NEAR account or an existing one.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Non-Fungible Token Drops
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: Non-Fungible Token drops are a special type that allows users to "preload" the drop with NFTs.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Public Sale Configurations
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: The public sale configuration gives the funder the ability to sell access keys in their drop with a variety of configurable behaviors such as the price, or a dedicated allowlist.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Simple Drops
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: The most basic type of drop is the simple kind. Any keys that are part of a simple drop can

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Time Configurations
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: Time configurations are particularly useful in defining limits on when a key may be used. This can have a wide range of applications from Subscriptions to Ticketing.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.title: Usage Configurations
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/GithubReadme/Typ.description: Usage configurations control behaviors surrounding how a key can be used. For example, dictating whether a key can be used to call only claim, or createaccountand_claim.

Concepts/KeypomProtocol/overview.title: Introduction to Keypom
Concepts/KeypomProtocol/overview.description: To view our debut talk at NEARCON 2022, click here.

Concepts/LinkdropsAndAccessKeys/linkdrop.title: How Linkdrops Work
Concepts/LinkdropsAndAccessKeys/linkdrop.description: For some background as to how linkdrops works on NEAR:

Concepts/LinkdropsAndAccessKeys/near-acc.title: NEAR Access Key Model
Concepts/LinkdropsAndAccessKeys/near-acc.description: A Keypair is generated locally and the pubkey is add to your account.

Concepts/welcome.title: Concepts
Concepts/welcome.description: Welcome to the concepts section of Keypom's developer documentation. Here you'll learn all about Keypom.

Cookbook/balances.title: Balances
Cookbook/balances.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to Keypom balances. This balance acts like a debit card, where you deposit $NEAR up front and create drop and interact with Keypom without needing to attach deposits to everything you do. For more on balances, see here.

Cookbook/drops/customizations/dropConfig.title: Drop Configurations
Cookbook/drops/customizations/dropConfig.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to drop configurations, including multi-use drops, and creating custom subaccounts.

Cookbook/drops/customizations/password.title: Password Protection
Cookbook/drops/customizations/password.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related password protecting your drops.

Cookbook/drops/customizations/saleConfig.title: Sale Configurations
Cookbook/drops/customizations/saleConfig.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to drops, including creating a drop, password protecting it, and utilizing Keypom arguments.

Cookbook/drops/customizations/timeConfig.title: Time Configurations
Cookbook/drops/customizations/timeConfig.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to time configurations, including start and end times, a time throttled drop, and using it to create a recurring payment tool.

Cookbook/drops/customizations/usageConfi.title: Usage Configurations
Cookbook/drops/customizations/usageConfi.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to claiming behavior and usage configurations. These will range from permissions for different types of claims, to automatically deleting the drop once all the keys have been used.

Cookbook/drops/fc.title: Function Call Drops
Cookbook/drops/fc.description: This part of the cookbook contains a quick overview on how to create an assortment of function call drops, using Keypom injected arguments, and attaching NFTs to your FC drop by lazy minting them.

Cookbook/drops/ft.title: Fungible Token Drops
Cookbook/drops/ft.description: This part of the cookbook contains a quick overview on how to create an FT drop.

Cookbook/drops/NEAR.title: Simple NEAR Drops
Cookbook/drops/NEAR.description: This part of the cookbook contains a quick guide on the simple NEAR drop.

Cookbook/drops/nft.title: Non-Fungible Token Drops
Cookbook/drops/nft.description: This part of the cookbook contains a quick overview on how to create an NFT drop.

Cookbook/drops/trial.title: Trial Account Drops
Cookbook/drops/trial.description: This part of the cookbook contains a quick overview on how to create a trial account drop.

Cookbook/keys.title: Keys
Cookbook/keys.description: This part of the cookbook contains everything related to keys in a drop, including adding keys to a drop, checking key usage and getting the number of active keys in a drop.

Cookbook/utilities.title: Utilities
Cookbook/utilities.description: This part of the cookbook contains utilities and miscellaneous common Keypom use cases. This includes creating NFT series, using the DAO bot and more.

Cookbook/welcome.title: Introduction
Cookbook/welcome.description: Welcome to the Keypom cookbook! Here you can explore Keypom's building blocks that help create awesome onboarding experiences. The idea of these pages is for them to act as a quick reference for common use cases when using the Keypom protocol. Every use case will have a corresponding code snippet using the Keypom JS SDK.

exec-summary.title: Keypom Executive Summary
exec-summary.description: To discover the features and details of Keypom, begin your journey here.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ContractSourc.title: Interface: ContractSourceMetadata
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ContractSourc.description: Information returned from getContractSourceMetadata about the deployed Keypom contract. This is part of NEP-330 and

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/CreateOrAddRe.title: Interface: CreateOrAddReturn
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/CreateOrAddRe.description: Information returned when creating a drop or adding keys via createDrop and addKeys respectively.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Drop.title: Interface: Drop
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Drop.description: Information related to a specific drop.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/DropConfig.title: Interface: DropConfig
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/DropConfig.description: Configurable options for any drop regardless of type.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/EnvVars.title: Interface: EnvVars
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/EnvVars.description: Important context that is used throughout the SDK. This is generated when initKeypom is called and can be retrieved by calling useKeypom.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FCData.title: Interface: FCData
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FCData.description: Information pertaining to all Function-Call drops. This should be passed in if the drop will be a Function-Call drop.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FTData.title: Interface: FTData
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FTData.description: Information pertaining to all Fungible-Token drops. This should be passed in if the drop will be used to transfer any fungible tokens.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Funder.title: Interface: Funder
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Funder.description: Outlines how the structure of the funder object should be passed into initKeypom or updateFunder. This contains important information such as the

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FungibleToken.title: Interface: FungibleTokenMetadata
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/FungibleToken.description: General structure of Fungible Token Metadata as per official NEP-148 standard (https://github.com/near/NEPs/blob/master/neps/nep-0148.md).

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/GeneratedKeyP.title: Interface: GeneratedKeyPairs
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/GeneratedKeyP.description: For each generated KeyPair (either through createDrop, addKeys or generateKeys), the public and private keys are returned.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/KeyInfo.title: Interface: KeyInfo
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/KeyInfo.description: Important information returned in many view calls regarding a specific access key.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Method.title: Interface: Method
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/Method.description: Outlines the information needed for any given method as part of a Function-Call drop.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/NFTData.title: Interface: NFTData
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/NFTData.description: General structure of a Non-Fungible Token drop. This should be passed into createDrop if you wish to have an NFT drop.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/NonFungibleTo.title: Interface: NonFungibleTokenMetadata
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/NonFungibleTo.description: General structure of Non-Fungible Token Metadata (in camelCase) as per official NEP-177 standard (https://github.com/near/NEPs/blob/master/neps/nep-0177.md).

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/PasswordPerUs.title: Interface: PasswordPerUse
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/PasswordPerUs.description: Keeps track of the password for a given key use. This should be passed in as an array for each key that has passwords.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ProtocolRetur.title: Interface: ProtocolReturnedDrop
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ProtocolRetur.description: Drop information returned from the Protocol. This interface is exactly the same as the Drop, except all the fields are

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ProtocolRetur.title: Interface: ProtocolReturnedPublicSaleConfig
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ProtocolRetur.description: Within the config, there are configurable options related to how keys can be sold and a funder can potentially make a profit.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/ProtocolRetur.title: Interface: ProtocolReturnedTimeConfig

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/PublicSaleCon.description: Within the config, there are configurable options related to how keys can be sold and a funder can potentially make a profit.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/SimpleData.title: Interface: SimpleData
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/SimpleData.description: Specific configurable information for Simple drops.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/TimeConfig.title: Interface: TimeConfig
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/TimeConfig.description: Within the config, there are configurable options related to timing such as how often a key can be used.

keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/UsageConfig.title: Interface: UsageConfig
keypom-sdk/Core/interfaces/UsageConfig.description: Within the config, there are configurable options related to how keys can be used. What permissions they have, whether an empty drop should be automatically deleted etc.

TrialAccounts/Creation/drop-creation.title: Introduction
TrialAccounts/Creation/drop-creation.description: Up until this point, you should have installed the Keypom SDK and its dependencies and should have a basic understanding of how trial accounts work and what is needed to create one. In this tutorial, you'll go through the process of creating the trial account drop that will be used to onboard users into the guest-book app.

TrialAccounts/Creation/getting-started.title: Introduction
TrialAccounts/Creation/getting-started.description: In the following tutorials, you'll learn how Trial Accounts work behind the scenes and how to create a basic drop that can be used to instantly sign a user into the guest-book app. You'll also learn about the underlying flow for the official Keypom wallet selector plugin and how it's used to create instant sign-in experiences for users.

TrialAccounts/Creation/integration.title: Introduction
TrialAccounts/Creation/integration.description: In the previous tutorial, you looked at the script necessary to create the trial account drop and how simple it was. In this tutorial, you'll start a local version of the guest-book app and see how easy it is to integrate and support trial accounts.

TrialAccounts/Creation/understanding-tri.title: Basis of Trial Accounts
TrialAccounts/Creation/understanding-tri.description: A Trial Account is simply an account on NEAR that has a set of pre-defined restrictions that limit the methods that it can call. This is achieved by deploying a very small no-std Rust smart contract on it (~25 kb or 0.25 $NEAR) that acts as a proxy, or middleman, for any outbound calls it makes.

TrialAccounts/introduction.title: Keypom Trial Accounts
TrialAccounts/introduction.description: Keypom Trial Accounts are an exciting new opportunity for Web3 apps to seamlessly onboard users whether they’re completely new to crypto or seasoned veterans. With the click of a link, users require no software, wallet setup, wallet connection, and are instantly signed into apps with their trial account, ready to make on-chain transactions.

TrialAccounts/offboarding.title: Introduction
TrialAccounts/offboarding.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to support trial accounts exiting into your wallet.

Tutorials/Advanced/CustomizedOnboarding/.title: Introduction
Tutorials/Advanced/CustomizedOnboarding/.description: One of the biggest pain-points with Web3 is that users need to fund wallets before they interact with a dApp. In Web2, a user can find value in an application by using it before they go through the messy onboarding process.

Tutorials/Advanced/daos/architecture.title: Solution Architecture
Tutorials/Advanced/daos/architecture.description: In this section, you'll break down the requirements for the onboarding experience in order to create a solution architecture. This means translating the features from the introduction into tangible goals for the specific Keypom drop and its configurations.

Tutorials/Advanced/daos/final.title: Final Product
Tutorials/Advanced/daos/final.description: Welcome to the last section of this DAO auto-registration tutorial! Here, you'll be seeing the full toolchain in action.

Tutorials/Advanced/daos/introduction.title: Introduction
Tutorials/Advanced/daos/introduction.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create a seamless DAO registration experience that allows you to onboard anyone directly into your DAO with the click of a link!

Tutorials/Advanced/daos/security.title: DAO Bot Exploit Solution
Tutorials/Advanced/daos/security.description: Up to this point, the DAO bot has a major security exploit. In this section, you'll learn about the exploit, how to fix it and how you can prevent similar exploits when writing Keypom compatible contracts in the future.

Tutorials/Advanced/subscriptions/introdu.title: Introduction
Tutorials/Advanced/subscriptions/introdu.description: Recurring payments are quite a common situation. Let’s say you need to send a contractor $50 USDC every week for 10 weeks. With Web2, you would need to provide a payment method and trust the end user with this sensitive information.

Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/architectur.title: Solution Architecture
Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/architectur.description: In this section, you'll break down the requirements of the ticketing system in order to better understand how to create a solution architecture. This means translating the features from the ticketing introduction into tangible goals for the specific Keypom drop and its configurations.

Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/bos-tool.title: BOS Version
Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/bos-tool.description: During the ETHGlobal Waterloo Hackathon, a chunk of this tutorial was ported over to BOS. This section is a quick guide on how to use it.

Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/final.title: Final Product
Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/final.description: Welcome to the last section of this ticketing app tutorial! Here, you'll be seeing the full app in action!

Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/introductio.title: Introduction
Tutorials/Advanced/ticketing/introductio.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create a seamless ticketing experience that is cheaper than alternative methods and can also handle very large audiences.

Tutorials/Basics/getting-started.title: Getting Started
Tutorials/Basics/getting-started.description: The primary goal of a Keypom drop is to send assets to users with the click of a link regardless of whether they have a wallet or not. These assets can come in many forms which will be broken down below.

Tutorials/BOS/welcome.title: Keypom BOS Components
Tutorials/BOS/welcome.description: Welcome! This a collection of useful BOS components from both Keypom and the community!

Tutorials/Misc/sign-txn.title: Methods of Signing Transactions
Tutorials/Misc/sign-txn.description: Place holder page to discuss different methods of signing transactions.

Tutorials/welcome.title: Examples and Tutorials
Tutorials/welcome.description: Welcome to the examples and tutorials section of Keypom's developer documentation. Here you'll learn how to use the power of Keypom to creating some awesome user onboarding experiences.
